title: Survival of the Fittest
author: John Ainsworth, Lee Mansfield, Steve Lyons, Jonathan Clements
filename: 131 - Survival of the Fittest - John Ainsworth, Lee Mansfield, Steve Lyons, Jonathan Clements_djvu.txt

elements.text: SYLVESTER MCCOY He means you no harm.
A Nazi scientist.
FABER A Nazi major.
SCHMIDT Klein’s mysterious assistant.
A man in search of lebensraum.
A newly-hatched Vrill Worker (female).
A Vrill Worker (female).
A wounded, “deaf” Vrill Warrior (neuter).
The faint voice of the departed Vrill Queen. (female)
BUTTERFLY/WARRIOR VRILLS: Newly-hatched Vrill Warriors (neuter).
VRILL, “THE WATCHER” : A small insect that sends signals through the nearby air reporting on intruders, arrivals and departures.
Alleged colonial paramilitary.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
EPISODE ONE SCENE 1. EXT KENYA JUNGLE —- OUTSIDE TARDIS.
FX SOUND OF TWO PEOPLE TRUDGING THROUGH JUNGLE - THEN STOP
Here we are.
The TARDIS
Yes. My work is done. With the British army here now, Sylvia and her husband are safe. Time for us to leave. But to where...? What am I going to do with you Klein?
It was your idea to take me with you.
Yes. Left alone you could do untold damage to the web of time. So, I have no choice.
In the TARDIS.

Which is exactly where you want to be, isn’t it? You’re still clinging to the notion of using my ship to recreate your lost Nazi future, aren’t you? But it will never happen, Klein. I’11 be with you every step of the way, watching every move you make.
I will never accept this reality, Doctor. I don’t belong here.
Such a limited mind. Earth is just one small world in a corner of the Universe. Perhaps an alternative perspective on morality and the passage of time will be beneficial for you.
Don’t patronise me.
I’m giving you the opportunity to experience a completely different world in a different time. Consider it an education.
SOUND OF TARDIS KEY BEING PUT IN LOCK. THE DOOR OPENS
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
After you... Elizabeth.
THE DOCTOR AND KLEIN ENTER THE TARDIS
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 2. INT. TARDIS
FX: TV MOVIE TARDIS BACKGROUND ATMOS AND FX
(SLIGHTLY DISAPPOINTED) ...Oh, it looks different.
I redecorated
I don’t like it
(HURT) Oh. Well, it was either this or the leopard-skin.
(FX: THE DOCTOR ACTIVATES A SWITCH ON THE CONSOLE AND THE
INTERIOR DOORS CLOSE.
Now..where to take you first Elizabeth? How about an exotic system far away from Earth above the galactic plane...
(FX: THE DOCTOR STARTS TO OPERATE THE CONTROLS. THE TARDIS DEMATERIALISES AND IS IN FLIGHT MODE)
And then what? Are we doomed to travel together in the TARDIS forever
You don’t belong anywhere anymore. You have no home for me to take you back to. You’re an anomaly.
An ‘anomaly’. That’s all I am to you, isn’t it? A problem without a solution. You know nothing of my home, of the life I left behind. Those I loved...
You’re right... We may be ideologically opposed. We may not trust each other or even like each other. Nevertheless, we are
now travelling companions. So, we need to find a way to cooperate on some level.
(SIGHS) Agreed...
So, why don’t we begin by you telling me something about the world you left behind? I’m a great believer in talking!
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
Why?
I’ve suggested you have a narrow view of the universe. You disagree with me. Prove to me I’m wrong.
Alright... What do you want to know?
Well, I confess to being somewhat curious about the events that lead to you making your first trip in the TARDIS?
You already know most of it.
Yes, but you only gave me the potted version. I’d like to know the details.
Oh very well, if you really must know
Here, you sit down and relax and I’1ll make us a nice cup of tea while I listen. How’s that?
(FX KLEIN SITS. THERE IS A CLATTER OF NOISE AS THE DOCTOR
TEA)

(SIGHS) It was 1962 and I was researching in physics at Cambridge when I was suddenly commandeered and was taken aboard a special military airship that would fly me to Berlin. Waiting for me aboard the ship was Major Jonas Faber...
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 3. INT. ZEPPELIN CONFERENCE ROOM
(FX: FADE UP LOW BACKGROUND HUM. THE CLINK OF GLASSES, TWO
BEING POURED.)
Ah, Elizabeth, come in. Sit down. You don’t mind if I call you Elizabeth do you?
Please do... Major. (SHE SITS).
Please, call me Jonas. And I trust you will forgive me for
sparing any blushes but may I say how beautiful you look. Freya made flesh! Will you take a drink?
No thank you, Major. I’d rather you just told me what this is all about. What’s so special about me that you need to personally travel all the way from Germany to ‘recruit’ me?
(LAUGHS) We have a new project that I am eager to get underway and your skills and experience are particularly suited to it.
You’re very kind, but there are others more qualified than me.
Bah! Qualifications are common Elizabeth but there is nothing common about you.
FX SOUND OF PAGES BEING FLICKED THROUGH

In these published works of yours you demonstrate a refreshing open mindedness that most in your field of expertise invariably lack. This will be of vital importance for our work ahead. As will good working relationships too.
I see... And what exactly is my new role? I was quite happy at Cambridge and my researches had reached a critical phase.

I’m sure your colleagues will carry on your good work. But, believe me, soon your pursuits at Cambridge will seem trivial. Your horizons are about to be broadened Elizabeth. Broadened beyond the boundaries of the Earth itself.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
Ah. I see. This is some elaborate attempt to get me to give scientific plausibility for the funding of further expeditions
to find the spear that penetrated Christ or the lost Ark of the Covenant..or stranded trolls from outer space?
Let me assure you, I am only interested in facts, not fantasy. Would it surprise you to learn that the Earth has already been visited by extraterrestrials on several occasions?
It would surprise me, yes.
Yet, you yourself have speculated on th xistence of intelligent beings on other worlds. You are clearly a believer.
If what you say is true, then why have I never heard about this before?
There would be panic on the streets if the public at large believed they were under threat from alien invaders.
You still haven’t answered my question. What precisely do you want me to do?

In a government depository in Berlin are various items of extraterrestrial technology recovered from alien incursions over the years. It will be your task to unlock the secrets of these devices to further the Reich’s cause.
Why now? If we’ve known of th xistence of aliens for years, why wait until now to begin research?
Chairman Hitler was, shall we say, reluctant to acknowledge th xistence of superior alien intelligences. He decreed that

all alien artefacts be sealed away and their existence denied. But, since his recent death, policies have changed. Hence my assignment to form this new unit. (BEAT) So Elizabeth my Freya... now you are interested, I’m sure?
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
I’m certainly... intrigued. (BEAT) You know, I think I will have that drink with you... Jonas.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 4. INT. THE TARDIS
And, of course, it was all true.

Yes. Once we reached Berlin I was given access to the bunker containing the alien tech. It was incredible. Weaponry, communications devices, the remnants of space vehicles and not just from one species either, but over a dozen.
You’d be surprised how many visitors your little world has received over the centuries. But mankind has a breathtaking ability to sweep things it can’t comprehend under the carpet of history.
Meeting aliens might be something you do every day, Doctor. But having long-held theories finally confirmed in reality was no small occasion for me.
And in amongst all this extraterrestrial jetsam and flotsam, you found the TARDIS.
No actually. It the TARDIS. Not with Jonas.
wasn’t until sometime later that I discovered until after I’d become much better acquainted
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 5. INT. FABER’S HOME
FX: CUTLERY IS PLACED ON PLATES AS A MEAL IS CONCLUDED
(SIGH’S CONTENTEDLY) Thank you, Jonas. Delicious. You are an excellent cook... for aman.
(LAUGHS) That surprises you? Here, let me refresh your glass... and then perhaps another early night for us?
SHARED LAUGHTER
FX: A LITTLE WINE IS POURED INTO A GLASS
So, any progress on the Drahvidian power core?
(SIGHS) No... At least not in the sense that I actually understand it. I can get it to work; I just don’t know why it works. And until I do, I can’t duplicate it.
Just imagine... Almost unlimited power - enough for an entire city - all in a device not much larger than a car. It could
change the world forever.
Perhaps more than you imagine. Don’t laugh but I was thinking about the possibility of it eventually being used as a power
source for... well, for time travel.
Time travel? That’s an... interesting notion. What made you
think of that?

Well... first there was obviously the utter torment of not being able to relive our first weekend in Paris together over and over again (SHARED LAUGHTER) Aside from that, temporal theory has always been of deep interest to me. It’s theoretically possible you know, but it would require a huge amount of energy to achieve. I wrote a thesis on it as part of my studies.
Yes, I recall...
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
Doesn’t it strike you as odd that of all the alien species that have visited Earth that we know of, none appear to have discovered time travel technology.
Well, actually...
Yes?
There was a time traveller. In fact he was instrumental in us winning the war?
What?! That’s incredible!
And also highly confidential. I’m only telling you because I know I can trust you to keep it to yourself.
Of course. But tell me more...

In 1944, two people from the future, a man and a girl, arrived at Colditz castle. The girl, ‘Ace’, was executed and the man, known only as ‘the Doctor’ escaped in his time machine. But he left behind a small device that contained what we now know as a laser.
Laser tech came from the future! I knew there was something odd about the speed of that breakthrough. Especially considering its importance.
From the laser w ventually developed nuclear weapons.
Allowing us to bomb New York and Moscow, forcing the surrender and winning us the war.
Precisely. To be honest, without those nuclear strikes, things may not have gone so well for the Reich.
Such a shame that the time machine itself was lost. At least it confirms time travel is possible. How exciting!
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
Actually, it isn’t lost. We have the machine in a high security bunker.
What?

Stupidly for him, the Doctor returned to Germany ten years later. His time ship appeared next to a border crossing check- point in the west. He ignored warnings from the troopers who saw him raise a rifle. They gunned him down. He was killed instantly. The odd thing was though, that when the guards inspected the corpse they discovered what they believed to have been a rifle was in fact just an old umbrella.
(FX: UNDER THE ABOVE SPEECH WE HEAR THE TARDIS MATERIALISE ON A RAINY NIGHT. THE DOOR OPENS. FOOTSTEPS IN THE MUD. GUARDS
‘STOP, OR WE FIRE’. THE FOOTSTEPS CONTINUE. THERE IS GUNFIRE. THE DOCTOR CRIES OUT AND HIS BODY HITS THE GROUND)
Curious. But the machine... Why have I not been given access to it along with the other alien technology?
Elizabeth, the thing makes me feel..uneasy.
Why?
You have clearly studied the science and theory of time travel, but have you considered the implications of actually using such a machine?
You mean changing history?
Yes, in the wrong hands, even the smallest interference with past events might result in catastrophic changes to the world we live in today.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 6. INT. THE TARDIS
Jonas was right. Time travelling does carry great responsibility.
How hypocritical of you, considering that you claim that it was your own carelessness that created my timeline.
Even I make mistakes.
Which is why you came back in 1955? To try and set things right?
I wouldn’t know about that. For me that hasn’t happened.
If it had, you would still be dead. You should be dead.
You’re too kind! Anyway, thanks to you Klein, I’m not dead.
I should have listened to Jonas. If I had, I would still be there with him now. Instead, it’s all gone... Just a memory...
BEAT
So, how did you convince Jonas to give you access to the TARDIS?

After Hitler’s death in 1961, the succeeding ruling body was soon weakened by divisions and internal conflict. A time machine would literally have the power to shape the future and guarantee the supremacy of the Reich - on Earth and perhaps beyond...
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 7. INT. FABER’S HOME.
Just think what we could achieve with a time machine, Jonas. We could avert threats to the stability of the Reich before they had even occurred.
In principal it sounds attractive, of course. But the risks would be too great. The damage that could be done.

If operated carefully and responsibly, the risks would be minimal. Do you really want to watch our world destroyed by in-fighting? The Reich still has enemies, they are just waiting for a moment of weakness to strike. And, of course, there is the potential threat from aliens...
I don’t know, Elizabeth...

And, of course, those who control such a machine would be held in the highest regard. You and I, Jonas. We could be heralded as the saviours of the Reich. You are a Major now, but with this time machine, you might one day even be the Fuhrer.
That’s... that’s just a fantasy, Elizabeth.
Is it? Think about it... At least give me access to the
Doctor’s machine. Allow me to study it, to understand its operating principles.
(NARRATING)

And, of course, reluctantly he did. It took some arm twisting - sometimes literally. Eventually though, the TARDIS was exhumed from the secret bunker where it had remained hidden for years and was brought to my laboratory. My excitement quickly disappeared though, when I discovered that couldn’t even gain access to the machine. The door was locked and I had no key. I tried to drill the lock but it was no use. High-speed, diamond tipped drills didn’t even leave a scratch. However, my attempts to force an entry did activate some kind of distress call, no doubt to alert you had you still been alive to receive it.
(FX: UNDER THE ABOVE SPEECH WE HEAR A DRILL AS IT TRIES TO PENETRATE THE TARDIS LOCK. AFTER A MOMENT A SHRILL ALARM SOUND
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
BE HEARD WHICH CONTINUES AFTER THE DRILL STOPS AND THEN FADES OUT)
And then, I realised you must have been carrying the key when you were shot. Immediately I requested access to your remains only to learn that soon after the shooting, your corpse had
been stolen.
SCENE
8. INT. TARDIS.
Stolen, eh? Why, I wonder, corpse? I’m much more fun when I’m alive.
Apparently it was assumed the corpse of a time
that
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
would someone want to steal my
to be trophy hunters. I dare say traveller would make for a rather
unique exhibit in an eccentric’s collection. Perhaps they had you stuffed?
How flattering.
So, without the key to the our plans. But it wasn’t long before new hope presented
iiavc
I had no hope of realising
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 9. INT. KLEIN’S LABORATORY
(FX: VARIOUS ELECTRONIC BLEEPS IN THE BACKGROUND AS
ARE CARRIED OUT. WE HEAR WHAT SOUNDS LIKE A
IRON BEING USED. A TRIM PHONE RINGS. THE SOLDERING STOPS AND THE PHONE IS ANSWERED)
Hello.
(DISTORT) Doctor Klein?
Yes. Who is this? How did you get this number?
(DISTORT) Doctor Klein, we need to meet. I have something that I think might be of interest to you.
Who is this? You have no business phoning here. I can have this call traced -
(DISTORT) My name is Schmidt. Johan Schmidt. You have in your possession a time machine do you not?
T -
(DISTORT) ..-And I have in my possession the key to that time machine.
(SLOWLY) What... Is this some kind of joke? Is Major Faber behind this?
Major who?
What..what is it you are after? Money?
(DISTORT)
I’m not interested in money, Doctor. I just want to help you. Meet me at the Cafe Berio on MaakenstraBke at eleven tonight. You’ll be quite safe.
FX: THERE IS A CLICK AS THE PHONE HANGS UP
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
(NARRATING)

I reasoned that he must be telling the truth about possessing the key. There was no other way he could have known about it. But how did he find me and how did he know I had the TARDIS? I was desperate to gain access to the ship and this seemed to be
my only hope. So, despite my fears, I decided I would go.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 10. INT. CAFE BERIO
(FX: IT IS RAINING. FOOTSTEPS APPROACH AND STOP. THE CAFE DOOR IS OPENED AND WE FOLLOW THE FOOTSTEPS INSIDE. A TUNE ON A
PLAYS IN THE BACKGROUND. SLOW FOOTSTEPS THEN STOP)
Johan Schmidt?
Doctor Klein I presume... Sorry to drag you out on a night like this. Sit down please. Can I get you something to drink?
I prefer tea myself, but I gather the cappuccino is excellent.
FX: A WOODEN CHAIR IS DRAGGED OUT AND KLEIN SITS
No thank you. I didn’t come here to socialise.
No. You came here for this...
FX: A KEY IS PLACE ON THE FORMICA TABLE
That’s it? The key?
FX: THE KEY IS PICKED UP
Yes. The key to your time machine. Or should I say, the Doctor’s time machine.
How do you know about the Doctor? Where did you get the key? Was it you who stole the Doctor’s body?
(SMALL LAUGH) In a manner of speaking, yes.
How do I know this is the real key?
Take it. Try it out. I guarantee it will open the lock.
You mean... you’re just going to give it to me?
I am. Yes.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
You want nothing in return?
Nothing.
I don’t understand...

You are going to do great things with your life Elizabeth, marvellous things. And I am offering you my services should you need them. That key will give you access to the time machine but you will then have to deduce the operating procedures. Could be tricky on your own...
And what makes you so qualified...?

Qualifications are common Dr Klein. What you need is someone with some insight into temporal mechanics.. It has been an interest of mine for quite a few years now. I’ve picked up some useful bits of know-how here and there. Copenhagen..and other places...
Even if that’s true, why would you want to help me?
Isn’t it obvious? You possess the only known time machine on the planet. For a man with my interests, the chance to examine such a machine is irresistible.
I see. Well... thank you for the offer. I’1ll1 let you know.
Excellent. I’1ll be here at the same time next Thursday. See
lizabeth...
you then, El]
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 11. INT. TARDIS
And the key fitted the TARDIS lock?
Of course. As soon as I got back from my meeting with Schmidt, I tried it. I don’t know what I expected to find inside, but
TLO‘Es asi
Bigger on the inside than the outside...
Yes. Quite. Suddenly I fully appreciated that I was dealing with technology far in advance of our own. If Schmidt really could help, I was going to need him.
But you had your doubts about him?
Of course. He’d more-or-less admitted to stealing your body.
What did Schmidt look like?
Young. Tall with long dark hair. Handsome in a gothic sort of way. Why do you ask?
Oh, just curious... So, despite your reservations, you enlisted Schmidt’s help?

Jonas wasn’t happy, of course. But, with some persuasion, he came to realise that any possibility that Schmidt might help was worth pursuing. So, the following week, I returned to Cafe Berio, but this time Jonas and an escort accompanied me...
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 12. INT. CAFE BERIO.
(FX: THE CAFE DOOR OPENS AND CLOSES. TWO SOLDIERS MARCH IN
BY KLEIN AND FABER)
Good evening Elizabeth. I see you’ve brought some friends with vou.
This is Major Faber...
What are you up to, Schmidt?
I’m not up to anything, Major. I’m only interested in the pursuit of science.
I find that quite difficult to believe. There is no record of anyone by your name matching your description. You are a non- person. A grave-robber. A criminal. Are you from Romany stock?
Jonas...

However... You have suggested to Doctor Klein here that you might possibly be able to assist her in her researches. I am doubtful of this myself, but it would be foolish of me not to explore all avenues in pursuit of this important work.
You won’t regret it Major.

For your sake I had better not. You will come with us now and tomorrow you will begin your work. You will be under armed guard at all times. Should Doctor Klein report that you are making no significant contribution to her work, you will be dealt with accordingly. Guards. Escort this man to the ‘guest’ quarters that have been prepared for him.
FX: A SCRAPE OF A CHAIR AS THE DOCTOR IS PULLED TO HIS FEET
(AS HE IS LEAD AWAY, OUT OF THE CAFE) Thank you Major. See you in the morning Elizabeth! Bright and early!
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
I hope we are doing the right thing, Elizabeth. I don’t like him. I feel he is... almost mocking us. I don’t like the idea of him working so closely with you.

You have taken precautions. I will be fine. If he can help me, and for some reason I believe that he can, we could soon be realising our plans. (THE SOUND OF KISSING) Come on. Let’s go home and drink to our destiny. A destiny we can shape ourselves.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 13. INT. TARDIS
And was Schmidt as helpful as you hoped?
Yes. He was. We made good progress. He seemed able to make the leap of faith into the unknown that eludes so many scientists. We were of the same mind, I think.
And, if I recall correctly from what you told me before, that’s when you discovered the TARDIS travel log?

Yes, we theorised that it should be possible to return the ship to destinations that it had most recently visited. But navigation and independent flight eluded us. Jonas strictly forbade me from attempting any journey until I was confident of being able to pilot the ship back home.
So, what finally prompted you return with the TARDIS to 1944?
Well, now I think about it, it was something that Schmidt said...
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 14. INT. OLD TARDIS
(NOTE THAT THIS TARDIS SHOULD BE THE ORIGINAL McCOY ERA TV TARDIS)
(FX: TARDIS CONTROLS ARE OPERATED FOLLOWED BY SOME DISCORDANT BLEEPS)
Ohhhh.... That’s a negative on test twenty-three. I was sure we were on the right path this time.
Hmmmm... we do seem to keep hitting dead ends don’t we? How frustrating!
If only we could stumble upon an instruction manual! Even if we did what are the chances of it being written in German?

(LAUGHTER) For all we know perhaps this panel on the console is a Ouija board! At least we could then ask the Doctor about the vessel’s operation from beyond the grave! (LAUGHING) (BEAT) It’s such a shame the Doctor was killed.
(GASP) That’s it! Oh... how can we have been so stupid?! The Doctor isn’t dead!
What?
In 1944 he’s still alive. We know how to access the travel log and return the ship back along its previous flight path...
Ahhhh...So we could travel back to Colditz in 1944, collect the Doctor and force him to explain the operating procedures of his ship.
Exactly. Yes. That has to be the way.
That’s brilliant Elizabeth! Now you’re beginning to think like a time traveller.
(NARRATING) But Jonas was less enthusiastic...
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 15. INT. FABER’S OFFICE
Are you out of your mind, Elizabeth?!!
But Jonas it’s the only way. With the Doctor under our control, we could gain access to the time machine’s full capabilities.
No! It is out of the question! Even if you were accompanied by a battalion of storm troopers there is no guarantee that you would even find the Doctor.
Of course we would. It’s a matter of historical record. We know exactly where and when the Doctor is.
Even so, he might refuse to assist you even if it meant his own death. Then you would be stranded. Trapped in the past. Unable to return to the here and now. To me...
No. The machines log should record the journey and we can use it to return here.
You can’t be certain of that. And don’t forget that your very
presence there would be interfering with the past. A moment in history that could well have been the crucial turning point in the war. If that laser device was lost or damaged as a result
of your presence, it could have disastrous consequences.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 16. INT. TARDIS
Jonas was right, wasn’t he? As a direct result of your
intervention, Ace’s CD player and the laser it contained never
fell into Nazi hands. Germany lost the war and history followed its natural course.
(SIGHS) Yes, I know that now, of course. I was so determined to secure a glorious future for the Reich and for Jonas and myself. I took a gamble with time...
And lost.
Yes. (BEAT) I would do anything to change the decision that I made next. I could still be there.... With him...
We all have to take personal responsibility for our actions. (BEAT) Go on, finish your story...
(DEEP BREATH) I went back to the lab and dismissed Schmidt’s guard, sending him on some fool’s errand. Then I told Schmidt that we were going to defy Jonas and make the journey anyway...
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 17. INT. KLEIN’S LABORATORY
You are a brave woman, Elizabeth. I told you that you would do great things.
Straight there. Straight back. I have a gun and even with just the two of us, I am confident we can apprehend the Doctor. We
will return to the exact moment that we left. Jonas won’t even know we made the trip until we are back.
Elizabeth, you will have to make this journey alone. I can’t go with you.
But... Why? This is what we’ve been working towards all along. I need you with me.
(DISTANT) No, you don’t Elizabeth.
(GASP) Jonas...
COCKING OF GUN
(APPROACHING) Schmidt, step away from her.
Put the gun down, Major. I don’t pose any threat to you, I am only -
(FX: TWO GUN SHOTS. SCHMIDT CRYS OUT AND COLLAPSES, GASPING TO THE FLOOR)
Jonas! What have you done?!

Just after you left my office, I finally received an intelligence report on ‘Johan Schmidt’. It’s not his real name of course. He has many names. It seems that for several years now, he has been assisting political prisoners to escape justice and has been actively undermining the Reich’s ethnic
cleansing programmes. Elizabeth, you have been colluding with a traitor and a criminal.
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
(GASPING FOR BREATH) No, it’s not true, Elizabeth. He’s just jealous. Jealous of our relationship and our successes. Don’t listen to him. Get in the TARDIS and go!
TARDIS?
The... the time machine.
No Elizabeth. This man has tricked you. There will be no more time experiments. I’m having this machine taken back to its vault where it can stay forever.
No, Jonas. This is our chance. Our chance to take control. To lead. Together at each other’s side.
Don’t do it, Elizabeth. I love you. And if you love me, you won’t get in that machine. Its cursed! I told you it made me feel uneasy.
(THERE IS A ROAR FROM SCHMIDT AS HE LAUNCHES HIMSELF AT FABER. THE TWO FALL TO THE GROUND FIGHTING.)
Do it Elizabeth. Go! You have to!!
I do love you, Jonas. And that’s why I must go. Soon you will be Fuhrer.
(FX: THE EXTERNAL DOOR TO THE TARDIS OPENS AND CLOSES. THE
DEMATERIALISES)
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
SCENE 18. INT. TARDIS
(TO HERSELF) If only I’d listened to Jonas and not Schmidt.
Perhaps Schmidt saw the bigger picture?
Like you, you mean? (BEAT) He said ‘TARDIS’.
What?
Just after Jonas shot him, Schmidt called it the TARDIS. I’d forgotten that. It meant nothing to me. I had never heard that name until I met you. (HAUNTED) How on Earth could Schmidt know it...?
The memory cheats! Perhaps your memory is playing tricks with you? I used to think Professor X was better in the 60s until I went back and watched it again..Even Vault Of The Cyborgs!
No, I know what I heard. He definitely said TARDIS.
(NERVOUSLY) Anyway, it’s all in the past now! Well, ‘a’ version of the past...’ Your’ past to be precise.

(UNEASY, ALMOST TALKING TO HERSELF NOT LISTENING TO THE DOCTOR) How could Schmidt have known? Yet another thing to haunt me for the rest of my life! I can’t let it go. Somehow I just ‘know’ that its important. I can ‘feel’ it..
(SIGHS RESIGNED) If it feels that important to you..then I suppose you should know.
Know what?
From my point of view, it never happened, but I suspect I know what I planned. Hearing your account confirms it.
What do you mean? What are you talking about?
SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
My ‘death’ was no accident. I arranged it. In actual fact I didn’t die at all.
Ridiculous. You were gunned down. Riddled with bullets. Nobody could survive that.
Ah, but a Time Lord could. What, for a human would be certain death for me simply triggered a regeneration. My body wasn’t stolen, it got up and walked away. Literally a new man.
Regeneration? Surely that’s impossible. What new man?
PAUSE
